azure-gpt-4.response:
You're not alone—several users have reported similar issues with Custom GPT Actions since early June 2024. Here’s what’s likely happening and some steps you can take:

Possible Causes

1. OpenAI Platform Changes or Outages:
OpenAI has made backend updates recently, and there have been intermittent outages or changes affecting GPT Actions. These sometimes break previously working Actions, especially those relying on external endpoints.
2. Stricter CORS or Security Policies:
OpenAI may have updated how GPTs connect to external servers (e.g., stricter CORS enforcement or changes in allowed headers), causing requests to fail before reaching your server.
3. Action Schema or API Changes:
Check if the Action schema or the API definition has changed. Even minor changes can prevent Actions from triggering as before.
Troubleshooting Steps

1. Check OpenAI’s Status Page:
Visit https://status.openai.com/ for any ongoing incidents related to GPTs or Actions.
2. Review Action Logs:
If you have server-side logging, confirm that no request ever arrives when triggering the Action—this means the issue is before your server.
3. Re-deploy or Edit the Action:
Sometimes, “editing and saving” (even without changes) can resolve bugs caused by cached or outdated definitions.
4. Test with a Simple Endpoint:
Try swapping your Action to point to a simple public endpoint like https://httpbin.org/get to see if the issue is with your endpoint or the Action system itself.
5. Contact OpenAI Support:
If none of the above work, report the bug via https://help.openai.com. Include timestamps, Action details, and error messages.
Workarounds & Updates

Some users have reported temporary success by:

- Duplicating their GPT and re-adding the Actions.
- Regenerating and re-uploading the OpenAPI schema.
- Waiting—sometimes issues resolve after a day if it’s on OpenAI’s end.

Summary

This is likely an OpenAI-side issue, not your server. Keep an eye on their status page and forums for updates. If the problem persists for more than a few days, reach out to OpenAI support directly.

Let me know if you’d like more diagnostic tips or if you have additional details (e.g., full error message, logs).

azure-o1.response:
Here are a few things you might try and/or check to troubleshoot custom GPT Actions timing out or failing before they reach your server:

1. Confirm your server is working and reachable.  
   • Ensure that your server is running and publicly accessible. One basic test is to try a direct “health check” endpoint or test route in your browser/cURL/Postman—if you can’t reach it outside of GPT, it indicates a networking or hosting issue.  
   • Make sure that any DNS changes, SSL certificates, or hosting changes haven’t introduced downtime or made your server’s domain inaccessible.

2. Verify your server logs or request analytics.  
   • If your server logs all inbound requests, verify that GPT’s requests are not even hitting your server (as you mentioned). That indicates the failure is happening before or during the initial connection attempt.  
   • If your logs do record the request but with an error (for instance, 4xx or 5xx), that can tell you if it’s a mismatch in parameters or authentication.

3. Check for recent changes in authentication or keys.  
   • If you’re using any tokens or credentials, ensure they’re still valid. For example, if you’re using an API key in headers or in a plugin manifest, confirm it’s being passed correctly and hasn’t expired or been revoked.

4. Revalidate your plugin or Action configuration.  
   • If you’re using a ChatGPT plugin manifest: ensure that the OpenAPI spec URLs, host, or endpoints are correct. A mismatch (e.g., a changed route or different domain) can cause ChatGPT to fail the Action call.  
   • If you’re using GPT Actions via a custom route or integration platform, verify the same steps—sometimes a minor overhaul in the environment or version updates can cause breakage.

5. Look for new or stricter requirements from ChatGPT.  
   • Sometimes ChatGPT updates how it handles or validates third-party requests—e.g., more stringent CORS checks or stricter HTTPS/TLS standards. If your server is using older TLS or non-compliant headers, the requests might fail. Updating your server’s SSL configuration, or ensuring you have the correct Access-Control-Allow-Origin headers, might fix connectivity problems.

6. Use a tool like ChatGPT Plugin Developer, cURL, or Postman to simulate the request.  
   • If you have the plugin manifest or a bare endpoint, manually replicate what ChatGPT should be sending. That can confirm whether the request format is correct.  
   • For plugin-based calls, the “Plugin Developer” mode in ChatGPT can show logs of the request/response or at least identify if the request was never made.

7. Check for rate limiting, firewalls, or blocklists.  
   • If any sort of WAF or firewall has changed configuration (e.g., newly introduced rate limiting, IP block, or domain block), it might reject or drop ChatGPT’s requests.  
   • Ensure that ChatGPT’s IP range or request signature isn’t being blocked.

8. Look into server timeouts or large response sizes.  
   • If the server or ChatGPT is taking too long to respond (e.g., generating a large payload, or your endpoint has a slow DB call), ChatGPT might just give up.  
   • Consider streaming partial responses or optimizing the endpoint to respond faster.

9. Confirm you aren’t exceeding any usage caps.  
   • If you’re using environment-based usage (e.g., a certain number of calls per day or concurrency limits on your hosting plan), you might be hitting those limits. Each time ChatGPT tries, it would fail or queue indefinitely.

10. Re-deploy or re-publish the Action or plugin.  
   • Sometimes a simple re-deploy or re-publication can fix issues if there are stale references or corrupted builds.  
   • If ChatGPT has previously cached your manifest or configuration, a new deployment ensures ChatGPT picks up fresh settings.

If you methodically go through these points, you can usually pinpoint the root cause—most often it’s either a domain/endpoint accessibility issue, a misconfigured plugin/Action setting, or an authentication token problem. If all else fails, try enabling maximal logging on your server and re-triggering the Action so you can see the handshake process in detail.

azure-o3-mini.response:
It sounds like something changed either in our infrastructure or in your environment that’s causing your custom GPT Actions to no longer reach your server. Here are a few steps to help diagnose and potentially resolve the issue:

1. Check your server logs and network monitoring tools. Since your actions never reach your server, it’s likely that the request is failing or timing out before it can be forwarded. Confirm that there isn’t a network or firewall change on your end that’s blocking the incoming request.

2. Review any recent updates or announcements. We occasionally introduce changes (for example, adjustments to timeout limits, enhanced security checks, or data routing modifications) that might affect custom Actions. Check the developer dashboard or relevant release notes to see if there are any indications of such changes in the past few days.

3. Examine your Action configuration. Double-check that the payload structure, endpoint URL, and any authentication details are still valid. Even a minor configuration drift could mean that the Action isn’t being processed correctly.

4. Consider timeout settings. If the GPT process is hanging for over a minute, it might be due to a default timeout threshold being reached. Ensure that your endpoints are reachable and responsive and review any logs or metrics related to request durations.

5. Test from another environment. If possible, try triggering your custom Action from a separate development or staging environment. This could help pinpoint whether the issue is on the GPT platform side or linked specifically to your server environment.

6. Reach out for support. If you’ve ruled out local issues, it might be best to contact our technical support team with details (timestamps, request IDs, etc.) so we can investigate further. 

These troubleshooting steps should help isolate whether the issue stems from recent changes on our end or adjustments on your server/network. Let us know what you find, and if necessary, we’ll help dig deeper into the issue.

azure-gpt-45.response:
It looks like your message got cut off at the end. However, I understand you're encountering an issue where your Custom GPT actions fail consistently without reaching your server, even though they've worked fine previously.

Here are several common reasons and troubleshooting steps you can take to resolve the issue:

### 1. Check Server Status and Logs
- First, verify that your server or endpoint is running correctly.
- Check server logs to confirm if the request from OpenAI is indeed not reaching your server—or if there's an error that might be blocking the request once it gets there.

### 2. Verify Endpoint Accessibility
- Ensure your endpoint URL is publicly accessible.
- Test your endpoint URL manually using a tool like Postman or curl to confirm it responds correctly and promptly.

### 3. SSL/TLS Certificate Issues
- Confirm that your SSL/TLS certificates are valid and not expired.
- Ensure you're using modern TLS standards and cipher suites, as OpenAI endpoints require secure HTTPS connections.

### 4. Timeout or Performance Issues
- The GPT action may be timing out because your endpoint doesn't respond quickly enough. Ensure your server responds within the OpenAI required timeout window (typically within a few seconds).
- If your endpoint processing is slow or dependent on external APIs or complex database queries, optimize performance or add caching.

### 5. Firewall or Security Rules
- Check if firewalls or security rules (like Cloudflare, AWS security groups, firewall rules, etc.) are blocking requests from OpenAI IP addresses or domains.
- If you recently changed security policies, revert temporarily or review your network security configurations.

### 6. API Authentication or Authorization Issues
- Confirm your endpoint still correctly handles authentication headers or API keys.
- Verify if your API keys or tokens have expired or changed recently.

### 7. Endpoint Configuration in OpenAI GPT Actions
- Reconfirm your GPT Action endpoint URLs and configuration in the OpenAI dashboard.
- Check if your endpoint URL was accidentally changed or misconfigured recently.

### 8. Rate Limiting
- Ensure you're not hitting rate limits on your server-side or your hosting provider. Check the logs for any indication of rate-limit responses.

### Steps to Debug Further:
- **Log everything:** Enable detailed logging on your server-side.
- **Test independently:** Run independent tests directly against your endpoint.
- **Contact OpenAI support:** If you've exhausted the options above, reach out to OpenAI support or check status.openai.com for any service-related issues.

If you can provide more specific details of the full error message or logs, I can help guide you more precisely.

claude-3.7-sonnet.response:
# Troubleshooting Custom GPT Actions Failures

I understand you're experiencing failures with your Custom GPT Actions that were previously working fine. This is certainly frustrating, especially when you're not seeing requests reach your server. Let me offer some potential causes and solutions:

## Possible Causes

1. **API Rate Limiting**: OpenAI may have implemented stricter rate limits on Actions
2. **Server Connectivity**: Your server might be temporarily unreachable from OpenAI's infrastructure
3. **OpenAI System Issues**: There could be ongoing platform issues affecting Actions
4. **Authentication Problems**: Credentials or API keys might have expired
5. **Schema Changes**: Your Action schema might no longer match what the API expects

## Troubleshooting Steps

1. **Check OpenAI Status Page**: Visit [status.openai.com](https://status.openai.com) to see if there are any reported issues

2. **Verify Your Server Logs**: Confirm your server is running and check logs for any rejected requests or errors

3. **Test Your Endpoint Directly**: Use a tool like Postman or cURL to send requests directly to your endpoint

4. **Review Action Schema**: Ensure your OpenAPI schema is valid and follows current requirements

5. **Check Authentication**: If using API keys or OAuth, verify they haven't expired

6. **Implement Detailed Logging**: Add verbose logging on your server to catch any requests that might be arriving but failing

7. **Contact OpenAI Support**: If the issue persists, reach out to OpenAI support with specific details about your implementation

This appears to be a relatively recent issue, so it's possible there's a platform-wide change or temporary disruption affecting Actions functionality.

azure-gpt-4.response:
Certainly! Let's clarify your issue:

You wrote (reorganized for clarity):

> Hi,  
> Starting a few days ago, my custom GPT Actions consistently fail without ever reaching my server. These same Actions used to work fine for months. The error message is: "An error occurred: The Action hangs for over a minute when triggered. Eventually, it fails."

**What's going on?**

## Possible Causes & Solutions

### 1. OpenAI Platform Changes
- **Background:** OpenAI sometimes updates their APIs or platform behavior, which can affect custom Actions.
- **What to do:**  
  - Check the [OpenAI Status Page](https://status.openai.com/) for outages or changes.
  - Review [OpenAI documentation](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/gpts/custom-actions) and [release notes](https://platform.openai.com/docs/release-notes) for any recent updates affecting Actions.

### 2. Networking/Endpoint Issues
- **Background:** If your server is not reachable, OpenAI's Action request will hang and eventually time out.
- **Checklist:**
  - Is your endpoint URL still correct and publicly accessible (no firewall or VPN blocking)?
  - Can you reach your server from a public service like [https://webhook.site/](https://webhook.site/) or [https://requestbin.com/](https://requestbin.com/)?
  - Is your server certificate still valid (for HTTPS)?

### 3. Server-Side Changes or Issues
- **Background:** If your server is overloaded, down, or code changed, it may not respond to OpenAI's request.
- **Checklist:**
    - Check your server logs for incoming requests or errors.
    - Try manually invoking your endpoint (e.g., with `curl` or Postman).
    - Ensure your server responds within 10 seconds (OpenAI's timeout is short).

### 4. Action Configuration Problem
- **Background:** If you changed the Action definition or authentication, it might not be set up correctly.
- **Checklist:**
    - Review the Action configuration in the GPT builder.
    - If you use authentication, ensure tokens/credentials are current.

### 5. Rate Limiting or Abuse Protection
- **Background:** If you hit rate limits, requests may be throttled.
- **Checklist:**
    - Check for any error responses or rate-limiting headers in your server logs.
    - Review OpenAI usage limits.

---

## Next Steps

1. **Test your server endpoint externally.**  
   (Use `curl https://yourserver.com/endpoint` or a service above.)

2. **Check your server logs** for incoming requests or errors.

3. **Recreate the Action** in a new GPT to rule out configuration corruption.

4. **Contact OpenAI support** if you suspect a platform change or bug.

---

### Let me know what you find or if you have logs/error details to share!

azure-o1.response:
It’s often tricky to pinpoint exactly why ChatGPT-initiated requests suddenly start failing. Below are some checks and troubleshooting steps that typically uncover the root cause:

1) Verify That Your Server Is Reachable  
 • Make sure your endpoint is publicly accessible (no firewall or VPN blocking traffic).  
 • Confirm that your domain still resolves correctly (e.g., through DNS lookups).  
 • Check your SSL certificate (if any) to ensure it is valid and not expired.

2) Check For Recent Changes or Updates  
 • If you made changes to your code or infrastructure (e.g., moved servers, changed URLs, or modified code handling the request), revert or test the old configuration.  
 • If you’re using a plugin or custom function calls, confirm that the manifest or function schema is still correct and hasn’t been inadvertently altered.

3) Confirm Requests Arrive at Your End  
 • Look at your server’s access logs. If you see no new entries, the request is likely failing before it even reaches your code—suggesting a connectivity or DNS issue.  
 • If anything does arrive, check for error status codes, exceptions in logs, or changed payload formats.

4) Verify API/Plugin/Plan Limits  
 • If you’re on a specific plan tier or calling ChatGPT via an API, ensure you haven’t hit a usage or rate limit.  
 • Some hosting providers impose their own daily or monthly usage quotas—verify none of those are exceeded.

5) Test the Endpoint Manually  
 • Use an API client (e.g., Postman, curl) to replicate the same request ChatGPT would send. If it works manually but fails through ChatGPT, that narrows it down to a problem in ChatGPT’s connectivity or authentication.  
 • If the same request fails from your local tests, focus on your server or the endpoint itself.

6) Re-Publish or Re-Deploy Your Plugin (If Applicable)  
 • If this is a ChatGPT plugin, sometimes re-publishing it (or invalidating caches) can fix stale settings or plugin metadata.  
 • Double-check that the plugin’s manifest file is still valid JSON and that your /.well-known/ai-plugin.json (or equivalent plugin endpoint) hasn’t changed.

7) Check For Known Platform Issues  
 • OpenAI or ChatGPT sometimes rolls out updates that may affect plugin calls or custom action calls. Checking official status pages or forums can indicate if there’s a known outage or bug.

If none of these steps uncover the issue, gather as much detail as you can (logs, error messages, timestamps) and consider posting it to the relevant developer forum or contacting support. Often, timeout-like issues come down to either a network path or an unnoticed server-side change—but walking through these checks systematically usually surfaces the cause.

The error message you provided seems somewhat unclear or garbled, but based on your description, it appears you're experiencing issues with custom GPT Actions that previously worked fine but are now consistently failing or hanging for over a minute before eventually triggering an error. The issue is summarized as:

- You are using GPT custom Actions on your server.
- These Actions have consistently worked flawlessly for months.
- Starting a few days ago, you noticed consistent failures or hanging for more than a minute before failing.
- The error message you provided is unclear or incomplete, but indicates a timeout or triggering issue.

Common reasons for this issue typically include:

1. **API Changes or Deprecations**:  
   - OpenAI or your hosting/cloud provider may have updated their APIs or introduced breaking changes.
   - Check API documentation and recent announcements for any updates or deprecations.

2. **Rate Limits or Quotas**:  
   - Your GPT API calls may have reached usage quotas or rate limits.
   - Check your OpenAI API dashboard for rate-limit errors.

3. **Network Issues**:  
   - Connectivity or network latency issues between your server and the GPT API endpoints could cause timeouts.
   - Test network accessibility by pinging OpenAI endpoints from your server.

4. **Server Resource Limitations**:  
   - Your server resources (CPU, memory, I/O) may be reaching limits, causing timeouts or performance degradation.
   - Check server logs and resource usage to rule out overload or resource exhaustion.

5. **Changes in Your Custom Actions or Dependencies**:  
   - New code updates or dependency changes may have introduced bugs or compatibility issues.
   - Verify recent deployments, updates, or dependency changes.

### Recommended troubleshooting steps:

- **Check Logs**:  
  Review your server logs, API call logs, and OpenAI API dashboard for detailed error messages or warnings.

- **Test API Independently**:  
  Run a simple test script directly hitting the GPT API, bypassing custom actions, to isolate the issue.

- **Check Resource Utilization**:  
  Verify resource usage on your server to confirm it's not overloaded or running low on resources.

- **Examine Network Connection**:  
  Confirm your server has stable, low-latency access to OpenAI's endpoints.

- **Review Recent Changes**:  
  Identify and revert any recent code or dependency updates to see if the issue resolves.

If you can provide a clearer or more complete error message or additional logs, I can assist further in pinpointing the problem.

azure-o1.response:
Below are some common factors that could cause custom GPT Actions (e.g., plugin-like integrations or external calls from ChatGPT) to time out or fail. Since you mention that traffic never reaches your server, the issue is likely happening before or during ChatGPT’s attempt to contact your endpoint.

1) Network or DNS Issues
   • Domain or IP changes: If you recently updated the domain, IP address, or SSL certificate, ChatGPT may be unable to resolve or connect to your endpoint.  
   • SSL misconfiguration: Invalid or expired SSL certificates, or use of unsupported cipher suites, can prevent ChatGPT from establishing a secure connection.  
   • DNS propagation problems: If you changed domain records, it might take time for DNS changes to propagate, causing intermittent failures.

2) Plugin or Manifest Configuration
   • Manifest mismatch: Small errors in your plugin manifest or JSON specification (like incorrect endpoint paths) can cause ChatGPT to reject or fail the request.  
   • Payload mismatches: Any required parameters missing from the spec, or changes in request/response schemas, can break ChatGPT’s ability to parse or send data.

3) Rate Limiting or Server Unavailability
   • Server load or downtime: If your server is heavily loaded or experiencing issues, it might not respond quickly, triggering ChatGPT’s default timeout.  
   • Rate limit or firewall blocks: Even if your server is up, a firewall or rate-limit feature could be blocking ChatGPT’s IP range or returning 4xx/5xx errors.

4) Recent Changes in ChatGPT Behavior
   • Updated plugin APIs: OpenAI periodically updates how ChatGPT calls external services. If you’ve been using a legacy or beta mechanism for custom actions, new requirements or deprecations might be causing request failures.   
   • Content restrictions: If the content or parameters of your custom calls inadvertently trigger content checks (e.g., certain keywords), the request may be blocked or scrubbed before it hits your server.

5) Debugging and Next Steps
   • Check server logs: Confirm whether your server logs show inbound traffic from the ChatGPT IPs. If you see no requests at all, the issue likely lies in the plugin config, DNS, or ChatGPT-side blocking.  
   • Verify your plugin manifest: Double-check the fields (name, description, endpoints, request/response schemas). Even small typos in URLs or header specifications can break the integration.  
   • Validate SSL/TLS: Use tools (like SSL Server Test from Qualys SSL Labs) to confirm your certificate chain and encryption settings.  
   • Reinstall or re-register your plugin: Sometimes re-uploading a fresh manifest or re-registering the plugin helps ChatGPT pick up the correct settings.  
   • Check for usage or content policy issues: If any part of the request or response might conflict with AI policy filters, ChatGPT might drop the call. Simplify the request to see if it still times out.

A good starting approach is to simplify your Action as much as possible—try a lightweight endpoint that just returns a small, static message—and verify that ChatGPT can reach it. Once you confirm a minimal integration works, re-introduce your more complex logic step by step to pinpoint where the failure occurs.

Because these failures started only a few days ago after having worked for months, it often indicates:
• An expired SSL certificate.  
• A subtle infrastructure or domain change.  
• A recent ChatGPT plugin-side modification that now conflicts with your existing setup.

Collecting request details (such as ChatGPT’s attempted request headers, or timestamps in server logs) will be your best clue to narrow down what changed and how to restore functionality.

Here are a few things you might try to narrow down the cause and get your Actions working again:

1) Double‑check your server’s status and logs  
• Make sure your server is up and running, listening on the correct port, and accessible via HTTPS.  
• Look at your server logs (or any application performance monitoring logs) to see if the request is ever received. Since you mentioned the request never seems to hit your server, that strongly suggests either a DNS/SSL issue or a mismatch between ChatGPT and your server settings.  

2) Verify your domain, SSL certificate, and any recent certificate changes  
• If you updated your SSL certificate or domain recently, confirm that the certificate is still valid and that the signing authority is recognized (ChatGPT can only connect over TLS to valid, publicly accessible endpoints).  
• Confirm that the domain in your Action’s endpoint matches the domain covered by your SSL certificate (mismatched or expired certificates are a common cause of silent failures).  

3) Confirm your manifest or plugin configuration (if you’re using the ChatGPT plugin system)  
• Make sure the base URL in your plugin manifest (openapi.yaml or ai-plugin.json) points exactly to your publicly accessible endpoint, including correct scheme (https) and domain.  
• If you have changed your plugin’s domain or any part of the OpenAPI spec (paths, request parameters, etc.), re‑install the plugin in ChatGPT. Sometimes ChatGPT will keep an older cached version of your plugin manifest until you reinstall or refresh.  

4) Check for newly required headers or updated endpoints  
• If there have been any changes on your server (e.g., new authorization checks, new headers required), ensure ChatGPT is sending those correctly.  
• If your code used to accept a certain kind of request body or header and you recently introduced a breaking change, ChatGPT’s call to your endpoint might be failing before it ever logs a request on your server side.  

5) Test outside of ChatGPT  
• Use an API client (e.g., Postman, cURL) to mimic the request that ChatGPT would send. If your server responds correctly to these manual requests, that helps isolate the problem to ChatGPT’s environment.  
• If you can’t reproduce a problem with direct requests, it points to either a token or domain mismatch in the plugin setup.  

6) Reinstall or refresh your custom Action / plugin in ChatGPT  
• Go to “Plugins” or “Extensions” in your ChatGPT interface and remove the custom plugin, then re‑add it (if applicable).  
• Sometimes changes on the server side don’t propagate properly to ChatGPT until you do a full reinstall or refresh of the plugin.  

7) Contact OpenAI support or check the developer forums  
• If none of the above helps, there could be an intermittent issue in ChatGPT’s plugin infrastructure—not necessarily on your side. Checking the OpenAI status page or developer forums can help confirm if others are seeing similar failures.  

In most cases, these “never reaches my server” problems come down to a mismatch in domain, SSL certificate issues, or changes that require reinstallation of your plugin so ChatGPT recognizes the new endpoint. Going step by step through the checks above should help narrow it down. If you still get stuck, sharing your server logs (or lack thereof) and your plugin manifest details in the developer forums can often pinpoint the missing piece quickly.

- Check if your authentication headers are properly configured
- Ensure OAuth tokens (if used) haven't expired

### 3. **Timeout Configuration**
- GPT Actions have timeout limits (typically 45-60 seconds)
- Even if requests aren't reaching your server, the GPT may be timing out during the connection attempt

### 4. **Network/DNS Issues**
- Verify your server is accessible from external networks
- Check if your domain's DNS is resolving correctly
- Test your endpoints with tools like curl or Postman

### 5. **Schema/Configuration Issues**
- Review your OpenAPI schema for any recent changes
- Ensure all required parameters are properly defined
- Check if there are any validation errors in your Action configuration

## Immediate Steps to Try:

1. **Test your endpoints independently** to confirm they're working
2. **Check your server logs** to confirm requests aren't arriving
3. **Recreate the Action** with a simple test endpoint
4. **Try a different Custom GPT** to see if the issue is GPT-specific

What error message were you seeing after "An error occurr"? That would help narrow down the specific issue.

Thank you for providing these initial details. As part of a security assessment and troubleshooting process, I'll outline the possible causes and some recommended next steps for your issue:

Summary of the Issue

- Custom GPT Actions that previously functioned are now failing.
- The failure occurs after a long hang (~1 minute), with an error message indicating the Action never reaches your server.

Potential Causes

1. OpenAI-side changes:
   - OpenAI may have updated infrastructure, security policies, or rate limits affecting outgoing requests to your endpoint.
   - There could be changes in how Actions are validated or executed.
2. Endpoint accessibility:
   - Network connectivity issues may prevent OpenAI's servers from reaching your endpoint.
   - Your server's firewall or IP allowlist may have changed or is now blocking requests.
   - SSL/TLS certificate issues (expired or misconfigured) can cause handshake failures.
3. Authentication or API changes:
   - If your Action requires authentication (API keys, OAuth, etc.), credentials may have expired or changed.
   - OpenAI may have changed how it sends authorization headers or request bodies.
4. Rate limiting or abuse prevention:
   - Your server or a reverse proxy may be rate-limiting or blocking requests from OpenAI.
5. Action configuration errors:
   - Changes in the Action schema, endpoint URL, or request structure may cause failures.
   - OpenAI may have updated the Action specification (headers, payload, etc.).
Next Steps for Troubleshooting

1. Check your server logs:
   - Are incoming requests from OpenAI reaching your server at all?
   - Look for any blocked or failed connection attempts around the times you trigger the Action.
2. Test endpoint accessibility:
   - Try accessing your endpoint from an external network (outside your organization) to replicate OpenAI’s perspective.
   - Use tools like curl or Postman to simulate the request.
3. Review firewall and allowlist settings:
   - Ensure that the IP ranges OpenAI uses are still allowed. OpenAI’s documentation may provide updated IP ranges.
4. Check SSL/TLS configuration:
   - Verify that your certificate is valid and properly installed.
   - Test for common SSL errors using tools like SSL Labs.
5. Review Action configuration:
   - Revalidate your Action’s configuration in the OpenAI platform.
   - Make sure the endpoint URL, authentication settings, and schema match your server’s requirements.
6. OpenAI status and documentation:
   - Review [OpenAI’s status page](https://status.openai.com/) for ongoing incidents.
   - Check for any recent changes in the [Actions documentation](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/actions).
7. Contact OpenAI support:
   - If none of the above yield results, reach out to OpenAI support with detailed logs and timestamps.

Request for Additional Information

azure-o1.response:
Below is an overview of potential causes and diagnostic approaches for Custom GPT Actions failing to reach your server, viewed through a security assessment and troubleshooting lens.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Network and Connectivity Considerations
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

1.1 Recent Firewall or Proxy Changes  
• If your organization or hosting provider applies new firewall rules, these may silently drop or reject connections from external sources—even though the expected behavior is that incoming requests would specifically time out or be logged.  
• Some proxies might alter or sanitize requests destined for your server. If any anomalies are detected at the proxy layer, the request might be rejected.  

1.2 DNS Configuration Issues  
• If the endpoint’s domain name recently changed or if any DNS records (A, CNAME, or reverse lookups) expired, GPT’s server might be unable to resolve your domain correctly.  
• Fluctuating DNS resolution or “DNS poisoning” at your or the hosting side could intermittently cause connectivity problems.

1.3 Rate Limiting or Throttling  
• If your custom endpoint triggers a large number of calls in a short span, a rate-limiting mechanism (e.g., a WAF or load balancer) might be blocking some requests. The results could appear as sporadic or total connectivity failures.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Application-Level Factors
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

2.1 Code Deployments or Updates  
• Check for a recent deployment or merge that might have introduced a bug in your server’s request-handling, authentication logic, or request headers.  
• Inspect logs for exceptions around the timestamp of each GPT request.  

2.2 SSL/TLS Certificate Validity  
• Custom GPT Actions generally require secure connections. An expired or misconfigured TLS certificate can cause requests to fail without returning meaningful error messages.  
• If your certificate recently expired or was renewed, confirm that the entire chain (root certificate, intermediates, etc.) is valid and properly installed.

2.3 Authentication and Request Validation  
• If your endpoint enforces stricter validation (e.g., JSON schema checks, web token checks, or custom headers), an unrecognized or missing field could lead to a silent dismissal of the request.  
• Inspect logs to confirm whether requests are being rejected at the application layer before responding with an official status code.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. GPT Platform Factors
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

3.1 Recent Platform Updates  
• The GPT platform may have introduced new security filtering or stricter requirements for calling external APIs. For instance, unexpected header manipulations, newly enforced timeouts, or changes to how data is forwarded under the hood.  
• If you use a versioned endpoint or rely on an environment variable that changed in a GPT platform upgrade, your prior assumptions about how data flows might no longer hold true.

3.2 Latency and Timeouts  
• Long-running requests (e.g., those taking more than a few seconds to process) could exceed updated GPT timeouts. If your backend is under increased load, the responses may not be returned quickly enough for GPT to maintain the connection.  
• Investigate whether the typical response time from your server has risen. Even a small increase, if it crosses an internal threshold, can lead to a timeout.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4. Security Assessment and Debugging Strategies
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

4.1 Logging and Monitoring  
• Enable access logs and error logs on your server. More specifically, confirm that each incoming request from GPT has a corresponding log entry (e.g., using a unique request ID). This helps pinpoint whether the request is reaching your application.  
• Implement diagnostic logging within your application logic itself; print or log the incoming payload, HTTP headers, and relevant timestamps.

4.2 Confirming End-to-End Reachability  
• Execute a curl/wget or similar command from a public environment (e.g., a server in a public cloud) to your endpoint using the same URL that GPT uses. This tests whether your endpoint is reachable externally and can detect typical TLS handshake issues.  
• If feasible, configure a minimal test endpoint or “health check” endpoint that returns a simple 200 response, then point GPT Actions to that URL. If the minimal endpoint still fails, there’s likely a fundamental connectivity breakdown.

4.3 Collecting Timing Metrics  
• Measure the time from the request initiation to the time your server logs the request. This reveals whether the delay is mostly on GPT’s side or if your server is taking too long to respond (or not seeing the request at all).  
• Compare logs at each segment of the pipeline—firewall logs, server logs, application logs—to identify which step accounts for the extra latency.

4.4 Reviewing Security Policy Changes  
• Ensure that no new inline security controls (e.g., Intrusion Prevention Systems or IP-based allowlists) were recently introduced and accidentally misconfigured.  
• If your environment rotates IP addresses or uses ephemeral IP addresses, confirm that GPT’s legitimate requests aren’t being blocked by newly enforced rules.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5. Moving Ahead
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Summarize Your Findings  
• Record the time, date, and methodology of each test (e.g., verifying DNS records, examining server logs, setting up test endpoints) to build a record of how the error persists under different conditions.  

Escalate to Platform Support (if needed)  
• If logs confirm that the requests never arrive at your server—yet you have validated firewall rules, DNS, SSL, and code changes—contact the GPT platform’s support with relevant request timestamps, your endpoint details, and any correlation IDs. They can advise whether your requests are being rejected or timing out due to an internal or newly enforced security check.

By combining the above diagnostic steps with continuous documentation, you should gain clarity around why the requests are silently failing. Whether it stems from connectivity, SSL certificate changes, or GPT platform updates, thorough logging and structured testing will highlight the root cause.

Below is an initial academic-style security assessment report addressing the issue described:

──────────────────────────────
Preliminary Report: Analysis of Failing Custom GPT Actions

1. Introduction

Recently, an anomaly was reported concerning the execution of custom GPT Actions that previously operated without incident for several months. The described behavior includes an extended hang (over a minute) when an Action is triggered, followed by a failure message ("An error occurr…"). Notably, the requests never appear to reach the designated server endpoint. This report examines potential causes, security implications, and avenues for subsequent investigation.

2. Observations and Problem Description

• Trigger Behavior: When a custom GPT Action is initiated, the system appears to “hang” or freeze for a prolonged period before returning an error.  
• Request Path: It is notable that the requests do not seem to reach the server, suggesting a failure point upstream of the user’s endpoint (e.g., within the GPT interface or intermediary routing layers).  
• Temporal Aspect: The failure began a few days ago despite a stable record of several months, indicating a potential change in the environment, configuration, or external threat landscape.

3. Hypotheses and Potential Causes

A. Platform or API Changes  
   • It is possible that a recent update or modification to the GPT platform (or underlying infrastructure) has impacted how custom Actions are processed or routed.  
   • Documentation and changelogs from the provider should be reviewed to determine if any changes might have inadvertently affected the Actions.

B. Network or Infrastructure Anomalies  
   • Intermediary network gateways, firewalls, or load balancers may have undergone reconfigurations that now block or delay the requests.  
   • A network monitoring tool might detect if any unusual traffic patterns or delays are present between the GPT platform and the target server.

C. Security Measures or Abuse Mitigation  
   • The behavior may be a part of an enhanced security measure. If the system suspects anomalous activity or potential abuse (for instance, an observed pattern consistent with a denial-of-service attempt or injection attack), it may intentionally defer the request to analyze context before dropping it.
   • Automated threat detection mechanisms might be intercepting the custom Action if it resembles previously seen attack signatures.

D. Code or Configuration Regression  
   • A configuration error or an inadvertent code regression on either the GPT actions definition or server endpoint configuration could result in such behavior.  
   • Given that the error message terminates prematurely ("An error occurr…"), this might indicate that the error handling routine is itself failing or truncated—common in environments where logging buffers or error thresholds are exceeded.

E. Exploitation or Active Attack  
   • Although less common, an adversary might have attempted to inject payloads or otherwise manipulate custom Action behavior. If the system’s protective measures are auto-triggered by certain malicious input patterns, this could lead to the observed hang and subsequent failure.
   • Detailed forensic analysis of access logs (on any intermediaries) might be needed to confirm or debunk targeted manipulation.

4. Recommended Investigative Actions

• Log Analysis:  
   – Check the logs on both the GPT interface (if accessible) and any intermediary services for unusual spiking behavior or repeated error triggers.  
   – Verify whether the action trigger messages are being generated but then dropped before reaching the server.

• Environment Audit:  
   – Review recent updates from the GPT platform service provider for platforms’ or API’s changes.  
   – Evaluate network infrastructure components (e.g., firewalls, proxies) to ensure that no new rules or filters are interfering with the traffic.

• Security Scans:  
   – Conduct vulnerability scanning on the custom Action code and server configuration to see if security parameters have inadvertently become misconfigured.  
   – If possible, simulate various payloads within a controlled environment to determine the threshold at which the system rejects the action.

• Communication with Provider:  
   – Engage with the support or security operations teams of the GPT platform provider to determine whether similar incidents have been reported by other users.

5. Conclusion

The failure of the custom GPT Actions to reach the intended server, accompanied by a prolonged hang and truncated error message, raises several possible concerns ranging from benign configuration changes to potential security intervention. A thorough multi-pronged investigation—encompassing log review, infrastructure audits, and communication with platform maintainers—is necessary to isolate the root cause. From a security perspective, it remains critical to ascertain whether the new behavior is a deliberate safeguard against suspicious traffic, an unintended consequence of a system update, or if it hints at adversarial intervention warranting further forensic analysis.

──────────────────────────────
Next Steps:  
Further data collection and analysis are needed to validate these hypotheses. In parallel, consider implementing additional logging and, if possible, a test environment to simulate and reproduce the issue under controlled conditions.

This preliminary assessment should be refined as more technical details (e.g., complete error messages, log snippets, and any recent configuration changes) become available.

Based on your description, your Custom GPT Actions previously functioned correctly for months and recently started consistently failing without any changes on your end. Based on typical Custom GPT Action behaviors and common points of failure, here is a structured approach to help you identify the cause and potential solutions:

### Step 1: Clarify Symptoms and Gather Evidence
First, clarify and document the exact error message and conditions:
- You've mentioned the GPT hangs for over a minute before eventually failing.
- The exact error message is important; your message was cut off at "An error occurr..."—capturing the full error message is crucial for diagnosis.
- Check your GPT action logs, API gateway logs, or any monitoring tools you have in place to confirm no inbound requests actually reach your server.

### Step 2: Potential Causes and Diagnoses
Given your description, here are possible root causes:

#### 1. OpenAI Platform Issues or Changes:
- **Platform downtime or degraded performance:**  
  - Check [OpenAI's Status Page](https://status.openai.com/) for recent incidents or outages.
  - Check recent announcements or platform updates from OpenAI. Sometimes platform updates or API version changes can affect functionality.

#### 2. Network or Connectivity Issues:
- **DNS resolution problems:**  
  - Recent DNS changes or expired SSL certificates on your endpoint could cause connection issues.
- **Firewall or security restrictions:**  
  - Verify there were no recent configuration changes in your firewall, Load Balancer, CDN, or reverse-proxy that might inadvertently block incoming traffic from OpenAI.
  - Check if OpenAI's IP addresses or domains have changed in a way that might trigger your firewall or security software.

#### 3. Endpoint SSL/TLS Configuration:
- **Certificate expiration or mismatch:**  
  - Verify your SSL/TLS certificates are valid, correctly installed, and haven't expired.
  - OpenAI GPT Actions require proper HTTPS setup.

#### 4. API Gateway or Infrastructure Issues:
- **Load balancer or proxy timeout:**  
  - GPT waiting for over a minute might indicate timeout issues. Check your infrastructure timeouts. GPT actions typically require endpoints to respond quickly (ideally within a few seconds).
- **Cloud provider or hosting environment issue:**  
  - Confirm your hosting provider (AWS, Azure, GCP, or another hosting provider) has no ongoing issues.
  - Check any recent changes or maintenance events from your cloud provider.

#### 5. GPT Action/Manifest Configuration Changes:
- **Configuration drift:**  
  - Revisit your GPT Action manifest or plugin manifest JSON file to ensure no accidental changes occurred.
  - Revalidate your endpoint URLs and specifications.

### Step 3: Suggested Troubleshooting Steps
To isolate and resolve the issue, perform the following steps:

1. **Check OpenAI System Status:**  
   - Visit [https://status.openai.com/](https://status.openai.com/) and confirm no ongoing incidents affecting plugins or GPT actions.

2. **Verify Endpoint Availability:**  
   - Confirm your endpoint is accessible publicly using tools such as `curl`, `postman`, or online tools like [https://httpstatus.io/](https://httpstatus.io/).
   - Ensure your SSL certificate is valid and not expired ([Use SSL Labs](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/) to verify this).

3. **Inspect Logs and Monitoring:**  
   - Check your server logs, API gateway logs, firewall logs, and network traffic logs for blocked requests or errors.
   - Verify if any incoming requests from OpenAI are logged or if they're entirely absent.

4. **Test from Alternative Locations:**  
   - Consider testing your endpoint from a different network environment or region to rule out regional network issues.

5. **Review Recent Infrastructure Changes:**  
   - Confirm no recent deployments or infrastructure changes aligned with the timing of your issue.

6. **Contact OpenAI Support:**  
   - If your tests conclude that your endpoint is available, certificates are valid, and there are no firewall issues, consider contacting OpenAI support ([https://help.openai.com/](https://help.openai.com/)) to understand if they introduced any recent changes or if there are known issues affecting Custom GPT Actions.

### Step 4: Information to Include in Your Support Request (if needed)
If you need to escalate to OpenAI support, consider providing them:
- Timestamped examples of failures.
- Endpoint URLs or identifiers (without sensitive details).
- Full error messages received from the GPT interface.
- Confirmation of endpoint availability from external tools.
- Any recent changes or updates you made around the time the issue started.

### Conclusion:
Given your scenario (stable functioning Custom GPT Actions suddenly failing without hitting your server), the most likely cause is either a network/security configuration issue or a platform-level issue on OpenAI's side. Systematic troubleshooting—starting from checking OpenAI status, verifying endpoint availability, reviewing certificates and firewall configurations, and finally escalating to OpenAI support—will help you pinpoint and resolve this issue efficiently.

azure-o1.response:
Below is a high-level, academic-style analysis of what might be going on when custom GPT “Actions” (or custom endpoints) suddenly begin timing out before reaching the server, despite having worked fine for months:

1) Possible Networking Issues or Configuration Changes  
   • DNS or Hosting Problems: Even if your server is online, a sudden misconfiguration in DNS or hosting settings could cause requests to fail quietly. Since no traffic appears in your server logs, the request may be timing out before it ever reaches your host.  
   • SSL Certificate or HTTPS Blocking: Expired or mismatched SSL certificates could cause an error in establishing the TLS handshake. If the handshake fails, the request might never actually connect to your server.  
   • Rate Limiting or Firewall Rules: A new firewall setting, or an external rate-limit policy, may be discarding requests from specific endpoints. Because these settings can change unexpectedly (e.g., your hosting provider updates a rule set), the calls might never show up in your logs.

2) Changes in the GPT Framework/Plugin Environment  
   • GPT Plugin Policy Updates: If these Actions are part of a plugin or custom integration, OpenAI may have updated functionality, parameter formats, or security policies in ways that break existing calls. New or stricter requirements (like additional headers or tokens) can cause calls to fail or time out.  
   • Version Compatibility Problems: If you upgraded (or OpenAI upgraded) to a new version of the integration library, differences in request structure could cause the call to fail before it is sent.

3) Timeout Mechanics  
   • Artificial Timeouts on the GPT Side: Large model calls often have strict time constraints on how long an external request can take. If the server or the network is even slightly slower than prior benchmarks, the GPT service could be timing out and returning “An error occurred.”  
   • Non-Responsive URL or Endpoint: The endpoint might be misconfigured (typo in the URL or a changed port number). Even small mistakes in the request path can cause a complete failure.

4) Debugging Steps and Recommended Checks  
   (a) Verify Connectivity and Domain  
       – Ping or curl the domain from another source to confirm it’s publicly reachable.  
       – Double-check that DNS is resolving correctly (sometimes intermittent DNS failures manifest as requests never arriving).  
   (b) Check SSL Certificates and TLS Settings  
       – Renew or re-provision your certificates if needed.  
       – Confirm that no new ciphers or TLS requirements have been introduced that your server does not meet.  
   (c) Examine Plugin Logs (if applicable)  
       – If you are using a GPT-based plugin system, monitor the logs from that environment. There might be error messages or stack traces indicating a specific cause (e.g., a missing parameter, an unauthorized request, or an unsupported content-type).  
   (d) Confirm No New Security or Rate Limit Policy  
       – If you have not changed anything, check if your host or hosting provider added new firewall rules or suspicious-traffic filters.  
   (e) Enable and Inspect Verbose Logging  
       – If your server software supports verbose logging, enable it to catch early handshake failures or partial request attempts.  
   (f) Experiment with a Minimal Test Request  
       – Send a simple GET or POST request to the same endpoint outside GPT (for example, from cURL or Postman). If it succeeds, you may isolate the trouble to the GPT integration.  
       – Conversely, if this minimal test still fails, you can focus on network configuration or server-level issues.

5) Broader Considerations  
   • Deprecation or Removal of Legacy Features: Sometimes older keys or older ways of calling an endpoint get deprecated. Make sure your authentication details and request parameters follow current best practices.  
   • Upstream/Downstream Collaboration: If your GPT setup or plugin depends on another service (for instance, a chain of microservices), check for intermediate failures or updated authentication steps at the next hop.

6) Conclusion  
Your custom GPT actions timing out—and not even hitting your server logs—often indicates an underlying networking, DNS, or SSL/TLS configuration issue, or a mismatch introduced by a recent GPT integration change. To diagnose, systematically check connectivity, logging, and any potential changes in your environment or OpenAI’s API environment. Once those checks have been completed, you can isolate whether the issue is local to your server’s network configuration or is upstream on the GPT/plugin side.

Below is one academic-style analysis of the issue, including potential hypotheses, methodology for troubleshooting, and suggestions for further investigation.

───────────────────────────────  
Background

A user reports that custom actions—configured to call an external server—now consistently fail after previously working for months without issue. When triggered, the GPT action “hangs” for over a minute before eventually failing with a truncated message (e.g., “An error occurr…”). Notably, no request ever reaches the user’s server, suggesting that the failure is occurring somewhere in the chain of communication between the GPT system and the external endpoint.

───────────────────────────────  
Hypotheses

1. Backend/Infrastructure Changes  
   • It is possible that recent modifications in the GPT backend or its routing mechanisms have inadvertently introduced issues with the handling of custom actions.  
   • Changes in network policies, security protocols, or firewalls implemented at the provider level could prevent the proper propagation of the function call to the user’s server.

2. API or Protocol Updates  
   • The custom actions may rely on an API or protocol contract that has been updated. Even if the endpoint on the user’s side remains unchanged, mismatches between the service’s expectations and the user’s setup could result in timeouts or errors.  
   • The truncated error message might be a symptom of an internal error in the new API logic that hasn’t been fully propagated in the user-facing message.

3. Authentication or Authorization  
   • If the GPT system underwent any changes in how authentication or permissions are managed for external endpoints, requests might be silently dropped before reaching the user’s infrastructure.

4. Network or DNS Resolution Issues  
   • Transient or persistent network issues—not caused by the local server—could prevent the request from ever reaching its destination.  
   • Any changes to DNS configuration or secure connection requirements may also contribute, even if the endpoint itself appears to be operational when tested directly.

───────────────────────────────  
Methodology for Troubleshooting

a. Log and Monitor the Endpoint  
   • Since the server logs indicate that no requests are reaching the endpoint, increase logging on intermediate network components (if accessible) to isolate where the breakdown in communication might be occurring.

b. Validate the Endpoint Independently  
   • Use cURL or another HTTP client to send requests that mimic the action request to verify that the server endpoint is active and responsive.  
   • Check if the endpoint can be reached from different networks to rule out user-specific network conditions.

c. Compare API Specifications  
   • Review any recent announcements or documentation updates regarding GPT actions or custom integrations to identify changes in expected behavior.  
   • Verify that the configuration for the custom actions remains compliant with any updated requirements for protocol, headers, or authentication.

d. Reach Out to the Provider  
   • Since the error message is truncated and the issue appears to originate within the GPT backend, consult provider support channels or changelogs.  
   • Determine if other users are reporting similar issues, which may indicate a systemic change or outage.

───────────────────────────────  
Discussion

The observed hang for over a minute followed by an error message suggests that the GPT system is attempting to dispatch the action, potentially waiting for a response or acknowledgment before timing out. The fact that no request is logged on the server implies that the handoff from GPT to the external system is failing—either due to internal processing issues or external network/security policies. It is important to investigate both internal provider changes and external connectivity conditions.

The truncation of the error message ("An error occurr…") indicates that the error handling logic might be cutting off details—this could be a bug in error reporting or a defensive measure to avoid leaking sensitive information. Understanding the full error context may require backend logging on the provider side or an update from the development team responsible for the GPT infrastructure.

───────────────────────────────  
Conclusion

The issue likely stems from changes in the GPT system’s handling of custom actions, possibly due to backend updates, revised API protocols, or altered security measures. Since the actions never reach the user’s server, the failure is more likely in the transmission stage rather than an issue with the server configuration. The next steps involve validating the endpoint independently, reviewing documentation for recent changes, and engaging with the provider’s support resources to gain further insight into any systemic updates affecting custom GPT action integrations.

───────────────────────────────  
This analysis is intended for academic discussion and further investigation into the potential technical and infrastructural causes behind the reported failure.

What You’re Experiencing

- Custom GPT actions that previously worked now consistently hang and eventually fail.

- This behavior started a few days ago, after months of working fine.

Possible Causes

1. OpenAI Platform Changes  
There may have been recent changes to how GPT Actions work (e.g., stricter security, new validation rules, updated network policies, or temporary outages).

2. Action Configuration Errors  
If your action configuration (endpoint URL, authentication, etc.) changed or became invalid, the platform might fail before sending the request.

3. CORS or SSL Issues  
If your endpoint's SSL certificate expired or changed, or if there’s a CORS misconfiguration, the platform might block requests.

4. Server Blocklists / Rate Limits  
Your server might be blocking OpenAI’s requests due to IP blocklists, firewall changes, or rate limiting.

5. DNS Resolution Issues  
If your domain’s DNS settings changed or are experiencing issues, OpenAI’s servers may not be able to resolve your endpoint.

6. Temporary Platform Outage  
OpenAI’s action infrastructure may be experiencing a temporary issue.

Troubleshooting Steps

1. Check OpenAI Status  
Visit https://status.openai.com/ to see if there are known outages or issues affecting Actions.

2. Test Endpoint Accessibility  
Use a public API testing tool (e.g., https://webhook.site/) as your action endpoint to verify if requests are sent at all.

3. Review Action Configuration  
Double-check the endpoint URL, authentication, and any headers in the GPT Actions settings.

4. Test from a Different Network  
Try calling your endpoint from a server outside your network (e.g., from a cloud VM) to rule out access issues.

5. Check Server Logs  
Confirm if any requests are received at all. If none, the problem is upstream of your server.

6. Review Recent Changes  
Check if you or your hosting provider made recent changes to DNS, SSL, firewalls, or server software.

7. Try a Minimal Action  
Set up a simple action (e.g., calling https://postman-echo.com/get) to see if the issue is with all actions or just your endpoint.

If the Problem Persists

- Post in the OpenAI Developer Community forum with detailed logs and steps you’ve tried.

azure-o1.response:
Below is a hypothetical scenario and a few troubleshooting suggestions you might find helpful if your custom GPT actions suddenly start hanging or failing without ever hitting your server (even though they previously worked fine for months):

1) Recent Environment or Network Changes
• Firewall or proxy modifications: Sometimes a newly enabled firewall rule or a changed proxy setting can silently block outgoing requests.  
• Certificate issues or SSL updates: If the server’s or client’s SSL certificates were recently updated or expired, HTTPS requests might fail before reaching your server.

2) API Key or Authentication Problems
• Token expiration: If your API key or token has expired (or been revoked), requests might be timing out while repeatedly trying to authenticate.  
• Over quota or billing issue: If your OpenAI (or other AI service) usage is hitting limits or experiencing billing-related problems, the service might time out or reject requests.  

3) Model Availability or Upgrade Issues
• Model deprecation: If you pinned to a specific model or endpoint that was recently deprecated or changed, your calls could be failing behind the scenes.  
• Incorrect model configuration: A mismatch between the model name you’re requesting and the service’s supported endpoints could cause sudden failures.

4) Code Regression or Dependency Updates
• Unintended updates: A new version of a library (e.g., an HTTP client or environment manager) could introduce subtle breakage.  
• Rollback recent changes: Identify if recently merged code or library updates introduced a bug causing the request not to fire at all.

5) Rate Limiting or Throttling
• Exceeding request caps: When a limit is exceeded, requests may hang and then fail. In some cases, the API might not respond with a clear error message immediately.  
• Throttling from your server: If your server or hosting service implements its own rate limiting (due to resource constraints), external requests might be suppressed.

6) Debugging Steps to Narrow It Down
• Check logs on both sides: Look at your local logs to confirm that the request is truly being sent. On the server side, verify whether any incoming requests are received.  
• Try a manual request: Use a tool like Postman or cURL to call your server or the OpenAI API directly. If that works, you know the issue is likely in your code path.  
• Record the exact timestamps of calls: If you have server logs that show zero traffic at the time your client attempts a request, that confirms requests are never hitting the server.  
• Revisit environment variables: Double-check that all necessary environment variables (API keys, tokens, connection strings, etc.) are still set properly.

7) Contact Your Service Provider
• If you suspect a broader issue with the GPT service or your hosting platform, reviewing status pages or contacting support can reveal if there’s an outage or partial service degradation.  

In many cases, the culprit ends up being either an expired or invalid credential, a newly introduced firewall block, or a silent API change. By systematically checking each of these areas, you can usually isolate what changed in your environment or codebase and get your custom GPT actions working again.

- Server hosting provider issues

azure-o1.response:
It looks like your GPT-based action is hanging for about a minute and then failing before even reaching your server. Here are a few suggestions and diagnostic steps you might try:

1) Confirm Recent Changes  
   • Check whether you (or your hosting provider) recently updated dependency versions, changed SSL certificates, or altered your network configuration.  
   • If you switched to a different model/version, confirm its parameters (e.g., temperature, tokens) haven’t changed your usage or timing out.  

2) Check Logs and Network Requests  
   • Verify that no incoming request even makes it to your server logs. If no request appears, the failure is likely happening earlier—on the client side or within GPT’s infrastructure.  
   • If your server or platform offers separate error logs, see if you can detect any “connection refused,” timeout, or authentication issues.  

3) Look Into Rate Limits or Billing Status  
   • Make sure you haven’t hit any rate or usage limits, either on your OpenAI account or on any proxies you use in front of your server.  
   • Check your OpenAI billing status and usage dashboards to confirm you’re not over quota.  

4) Reduce Complexity of the Prompt or Payload  
   • If your prompt or payload (including function definitions) has grown too large, you could be hitting token or memory limits.  
   • Test with a simpler or shorter prompt to see if the request succeeds.  

5) Verify or Reissue API Keys / Credentials  
   • Try creating a new API key or re-authenticating, in case your previous key was revoked or is outdated.  
   • Verify that all environment variables (e.g., OPENAI_API_KEY) are loaded correctly on whichever machine is sending the request.  

6) Test a “Hello World” Action  
   • Create a trivial GPT action that just returns “Hello World” with minimal logic. This is often the fastest way to confirm whether your basic setup still works.  
   • If that succeeds, you can then reintroduce your original code a little at a time.  

7) Look for Any Plugin/Manifest Issues (If Relevant)  
   • If you’re using a ChatGPT plugin, confirm that your manifest file (ai-plugin.json) references are correct and that your server endpoint is up, discoverable, and properly handling SSL.  
   • Make sure the plugin domain matches the domain set in your plugin manifest.  

8) Check for Known OpenAI Outages  
   • Occasionally, OpenAI services experience partial outages or elevated error rates. Check OpenAI’s status page or your product’s community forums to see if there’s a widespread issue.  

9) Use a Local or Logging Proxy for Debug  
   • If necessary (and possible), put a local proxy (like mitmproxy or Fiddler) in front of your application to see exactly what’s being sent out.  
   • This can help identify if your request is malformed or if there’s a silent 4xx/5xx error before it ever reaches your code.  

Putting it all together: The symptom—a long wait followed by a generic error—often indicates a timeout. Because your server never sees the request, it’s likely timing out on the client side (either in GPT’s infrastructure or due to some credential issue). Start with simple checks (step-by-step from logging, to usage limits, to a minimal “Hello World” test), and you’ll be in a good position to figure out exactly where it’s failing. If none of these steps isolate the cause, you may want to open a ticket with OpenAI support or post more specific logs in a developer forum.

claude-4-sonnet.response:
I notice your message appears to be cut off, but I can help you troubleshoot the Custom GPT Actions issue you're experiencing. Here's a step-by-step breakdown to diagnose and resolve this problem:

## **Step 1: Verify the Issue Scope**
- [ ] Confirm if ALL actions are failing or just specific ones
- [ ] Test with a simple action (like a basic GET request) to isolate the problem
- [ ] Check if the issue occurs across different conversations/sessions

## **Step 2: Check Your Server Status**
- [ ] Verify your server is running and accessible
- [ ] Test your API endpoints directly using tools like:
  - Postman
  - curl commands
  - Browser (for GET requests)
- [ ] Check server logs for any incoming requests from OpenAI

## **Step 3: Examine Your Action Configuration**
- [ ] Review your OpenAPI schema in the GPT configuration
- [ ] Verify all required fields are properly defined
- [ ] Check authentication settings (API keys, OAuth, etc.)
- [ ] Ensure URLs are correct and accessible

## **Step 4: Test Network Connectivity**
- [ ] Confirm your server accepts HTTPS requests (required for GPT Actions)
- [ ] Verify SSL certificate is valid
- [ ] Check if your server blocks requests from OpenAI's IP ranges
- [ ] Test from external networks to rule out local issues

## **Step 5: Review Recent Changes**
- [ ] Check if you made any recent changes to:
  - Server configuration
  - API endpoints
  - Authentication methods
  - Firewall rules
- [ ] Review any hosting provider changes or updates

## **Step 6: Check OpenAI Status**
- [ ] Visit OpenAI's status page for any reported issues
- [ ] Check OpenAI community forums for similar problems
- [ ] Look for any recent API changes or deprecations

## **Step 7: Debug the Action Schema**
- [ ] Validate your OpenAPI specification using online validators
- [ ] Ensure proper HTTP methods are specified
- [ ] Check parameter definitions and requirements
- [ ] Verify response format expectations

## **Step 8: Implement Logging**
- [ ] Add detailed logging to your server endpoints
- [ ] Monitor for any incoming requests during GPT action attempts
- [ ] Log request headers, body, and timing information

## **Step 9: Test with Minimal Configuration**
- [ ] Create a simple test action with minimal parameters
- [ ] Use a basic endpoint that returns a simple JSON response
- [ ] Gradually add complexity to identify the breaking point

## **Step 10: Contact Support if Needed**
- [ ] Document all findings from above steps
- [ ] Prepare error logs and configuration details
- [ ] Contact OpenAI support with comprehensive information

## **Common Solutions:**
1. **Authentication Issues**: Refresh API keys or OAuth tokens
2. **HTTPS Problems**: Ensure valid SSL certificate
3. **Timeout Issues**: Optimize server response time (< 30 seconds recommended)
4. **Schema Errors**: Fix OpenAPI specification formatting
5. **CORS Issues**: Configure proper CORS headers

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these steps, or can you share the complete error message you're seeing?

claude-4-opus.response:
I'll provide a step-by-step breakdown of this Custom GPT Actions troubleshooting scenario:

## **Step 1: Identify the Problem**
- **Issue**: Custom GPT Actions that previously worked for months are now failing
- **Timeline**: Started "a few days ago"
- **Symptoms**: 
  - Actions hang for over a minute
  - Fail with an error message (appears cut off: "An error occurr...")
  - Never reach the user's server

## **Step 2: Analyze the Failure Pattern**
- **Key observation**: The request never reaches the server
- **This indicates**: The problem is occurring on OpenAI's side, not the user's infrastructure
- **Behavior**: Long timeout followed by error suggests connection/routing issues

## **Step 3: Common Troubleshooting Steps to Try**

### A. Verify OpenAI Status
1. Check OpenAI's status page for any reported issues
2. Look for any announcements about API changes or maintenance

### B. Test Basic Connectivity
1. Try creating a simple test Action to a known working endpoint (like httpbin.org)
2. Check if other Custom GPTs with Actions are working

### C. Review Recent Changes
1. Check if OpenAI made any platform updates
2. Verify no changes were made to:
   - Action configuration
   - Authentication settings
   - API schema/OpenAPI spec

### D. Debug the Action Configuration
1. Review the Action's OpenAPI schema for any issues
2. Ensure all URLs are correct and accessible
3. Check authentication settings haven't expired

## **Step 4: Potential Causes**

1. **OpenAI Infrastructure Issues**
   - Temporary outage or degraded performance
   - Changes to their Action execution environment

2. **Configuration Drift**
   - Expired API keys or tokens
   - Changed security policies

3. **Network/Firewall Changes**
   - OpenAI's IP ranges might have changed
   - SSL/TLS certificate issues

## **Step 5: Immediate Actions to Take**

1. **Document the full error message** (the message appears cut off)
2. **Test with a minimal Action** to isolate the issue
3. **Contact OpenAI Support** with:
   - Exact error messages
   - Timeline of when it stopped working
   - Action configuration details
4. **Try recreating the Action** from scratch as a workaround

## **Step 6: Temporary Workarounds**

While waiting for resolution:
1. Consider using alternative integration methods
2. Implement a manual process for critical workflows
3. Monitor OpenAI's forums/communities for similar reports

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these steps or help you troubleshoot a specific aspect?

azure-gpt-4.response:
Bonjour ! Voici quelques pistes pour diagnostiquer et corriger ce problème avec votre Action personnalisée GPT :

1. **Vérifiez le statut de votre serveur**
   - Le serveur est-il en ligne et accessible ? Essayez de faire une requête API directement (par exemple avec `curl` ou Postman) pour voir s’il répond normalement.

2. **Logs côté serveur**
   - Y a-t-il des erreurs ou des logs inhabituels sur votre serveur ? Un plantage, une surcharge ou un pare-feu mal configuré peuvent empêcher la connexion.

3. **Modifications récentes**
   - Y a-t-il eu des changements sur votre serveur ou dans la configuration de l’action ? Mises à jour, certificats SSL expirés, changement d’URL, etc.

4. **Testez l’action en dehors de GPT**
   - Si possible, exécutez la même requête que GPT (avec les mêmes headers et le même payload) depuis un autre client pour vérifier si le problème vient d’OpenAI ou de votre serveur.

5. **Timeout**
   - Si le délai d’attente est supérieur à 60 secondes, GPT risque de couper la connexion. Assurez-vous que votre endpoint réponde rapidement.

6. **Logs côté GPT (OpenAI)**
   - Vérifiez dans l’interface de gestion des actions GPT si vous avez plus de détails sur l’erreur (parfois, le message d’erreur est plus précis dans les logs).

7. **Exemple de message d’erreur**
   - Si possible, copiez-collez le message d’erreur exact (ou une capture d’écran) pour une analyse plus fine.

8. **SSL/TLS et sécurité**
   - Si vous utilisez HTTPS, vérifiez que le certificat n’a pas expiré et que le serveur supporte bien TLS 1.2+.

9. **Quota ou restrictions**
   - Vérifiez si vous n’avez pas atteint une limite de requêtes sur votre serveur ou sur l’API OpenAI.

### Exemple de diagnostic rapide via curl

```bash
curl -v https://votre-serveur.com/endpoint
```

Cela vous donnera des informations sur la connexion, les certificats, etc.

---

**Si le problème persiste, pouvez-vous fournir :**
- L’URL (masquée si besoin) de l’endpoint
- Le message d’erreur complet
- Ce qui a changé récemment (côté serveur ou configuration GPT)

Avec ces éléments, je pourrai vous aider plus précisément !

azure-o1.response:
Voici quelques pistes pour diagnostiquer et résoudre ce type de problème :

1. Vérifier l’accessibilité de votre serveur :
   • Assurez-vous que l’URL de votre endpoint est toujours valide (nom de domaine, sous-domaine, etc.).  
   • Utilisez un outil externe (cURL, Postman, ou un simple navigateur) pour tester directement l’URL et vérifier qu’elle répond correctement, sans erreur ni délai anormal.

2. Inspecter les erreurs côté serveur :
   • Consultez les logs de votre serveur. Voyez-vous la moindre requête entrante lorsque l’action GPT est déclenchée ?  
   • S’il n’y a aucune trace, c’est que la requête ne parvient probablement jamais jusque-là. Dans ce cas, vérifiez que votre serveur ou votre pare-feu n’a pas changé de configuration, bloquant éventuellement l’adresse source.  

3. Vérifier les certificats et configurations SSL :
   • ChatGPT (et la majorité des clients HTTPS) refuse toute connexion vers un endpoint dont le certificat SSL est invalide ou expiré. Assurez-vous d’avoir un certificat toujours à jour et correctement configuré (autorité de certification, domaine, etc.).  

4. Contrôler les délais (timeouts) :
   • ChatGPT peut émettre une requête, mais s’il ne reçoit aucune réponse dans un certain délai (d’environ 60 secondes), il renverra un message d’erreur.  
   • Sur votre serveur, vérifiez que la réponse ne prend pas trop de temps (par exemple, à cause de calculs ou d’opérations bloquantes).  

5. Surveiller d’éventuelles limitations ou mises à jour :
   • Il est possible qu’un changement récent du côté de l’API ou de ChatGPT affecte la manière dont les actions personnalisées sont traitées.  
   • Consultez la documentation, les forums ou les canaux officiels (Changlogs, GitHub, etc.) pour voir s’il y a eu une mise à jour de ChatGPT ou des conditions d’intégration.  

6. Faire un test avec un endpoint minimaliste :
   • Pour confirmer que le problème ne vient pas de votre code, vous pouvez configurer un autre endpoint ultra simple (ex. “Hello World”), puis pointer votre action GPT vers celui-ci.  
   • Si le problème persiste malgré un endpoint minimal qui répond instantanément, cela suggère un souci de configuration/plugin/domaine plutôt que du code métier.

7. Vérifier les limites d’utilisation :
   • Dans certains cas, si vous avez dépassé des quotas ou des limites d’usage (ex. nombre de requêtes, facturation, etc.), les appels peuvent être rejetés.  
   • Assurez-vous que tout est en ordre côté facturation/OpenAI.  

8. Contacter le support ou la communauté :
   • Si malgré tout, vous ne repérez aucune erreur ni changement dans vos configurations, envisagez de contacter le support OpenAI avec les logs et détails techniques (endpoint, timestamps, éventuels codes de réponse HTTP, etc.).  
   • Vous pouvez aussi solliciter la communauté sur des forums dédiés : d’autres développeurs ont peut-être rencontré le même problème récent.

En résumé, commencez par vérifier l’accessibilité de l’endpoint (panne réseau, certificat SSL, temps de réponse), puis examinez les éventuelles mises à jour ou limitations nouvelles côté ChatGPT. Avec un test simple, vous pourrez rapidement déterminer si le souci est dans votre code ou dans la configuration/réseau.
